section.title: The concept of the bridi
section.para: bridiconcept of This chapter gives diagrammed examples of basic Lojban sentence structures. The most general pattern is covered first, followed by successive variations on the basic components of the Lojban sentence. There are many more capabilities not covered in this chapter, but covered in detail in later chapters, so this chapter is a quick tour of the material later covered more slowly throughout the book. It also introduces most of the Lojban words used to discuss Lojban grammar.
Let us consider John and Sam and three statements about them:

example.para: John is the father of Sam.

section.para:
sumtirelation with bridi brivlarelation to bridi predicationcompared with bridi bridicompared with predication predicationas a relationship relationshipactive/static/attributive compared These examples all describe relationships between John and Sam. However, in English, we use the noun
father to describe a static relationship in , the verb hits to describe an active relationship in
, and the adjective taller to describe an attributive relationship in
. In Lojban we make no such grammatical distinctions; these three sentences, when expressed in Lojban, are structurally identical. The same part of speech is used to represent the relationship. In formal logic this whole structure is called a predication; in Lojban it is called a bridi, and the central part of speech is the selbri. Logicians refer to the things thus related as arguments, while Lojbanists call them sumti. These Lojban terms will be used for the rest of the book.

textobject.phrase: bridi (predicate) ______________|__________________ | | John is the father of Sam |____| |______________| |___| | | | sumti selbri sumti (argument)

section.para: In a relationship, there are a definite number of things being related. In English, for example, give has three places: the donor, the recipient and the gift. For example:
and
mean two different things because the relative positions of John and Sam have been switched. Further,
seems strange to us merely because the places are being filled by unorthodox arguments. The relationship expressed by give has not changed.

place structuredefinition of In Lojban, each selbri has a specified number and type of arguments, known collectively as its place structure. The simplest kind of selbri consists of a single root word, called a gismu, and the definition in a dictionary gives the place structure explicitly. The primary task of constructing a Lojban sentence, after choosing the relationship itself, is deciding what you will use to fill in the sumti places.

This book uses the Lojban terms bridi, sumti, and selbri, because it is best to come to understand them independently of the English associations of the corresponding words, which are only roughly similar in meaning anyhow.

section.title: Pronunciation
section.para: pronunciationquick-tour version Detailed pronunciation and spelling rules are given in , but what follows will keep the reader from going too far astray while digesting this chapter.

vowelspronunciation ofquick-tour version Lojban has six recognized vowels: a, e, i, o, u and y. The first five are roughly pronounced as a as in father, e as in let, i as in machine, o as in dome and u as in flute. y is pronounced as the sound called schwa, that is, as the unstressed a as in about or around.

consonantspronunciation ofquick-tour version Twelve consonants in Lojban are pronounced more or less as their counterparts are in English: b, d, f, k, l, m, n, p, r, t, v and z. The letter c, on the other hand is pronounced as the sh in hush, while j is its voiced counterpart, the sound of the s in pleasure. g is always pronounced as it is in gift, never as in giant. s is as in sell, never as in rose. The sound of x is not found in English in normal words. It is found as ch in Scottish loch, as j in Spanish junta, and as ch in German Bach; it also appears in the English interjection yecchh!. It gets easier to say as you practice it. The letter r can be trilled, but doesn't have to be.

diphthongspronunciation ofquick-tour version The Lojban diphthongs ai, ei, oi, and au are pronounced much as in the English words sigh, say, boy, and how. Other Lojban diphthongs begin with an i pronounced like English y (for example, io is pronounced yo) or else with a u pronounced like English w (for example, ua is pronounced wa).

periodquick-tour version commaquick-tour version apostrophequick-tour version Lojban also has three semi-letters: the period, the comma and the apostrophe. The period represents a glottal stop or a pause; it is a required stoppage of the flow of air in the speech stream. The apostrophe sounds just like the English letter
h. Unlike a regular consonant, it is not found at the beginning or end of a word, nor is it found adjacent to a consonant; it is only found between two vowels. The comma has no sound associated with it, and is used to separate syllables that might ordinarily run together. It is not used in this chapter.

stressquick-tour version Stress falls on the next to the last syllable of all words, unless that vowel is y, which is never stressed; in such words the third-to-last syllable is stressed. If a word only has one syllable, then that syllable is not stressed.
All Lojban words are pronounced as they are spelled: there are no silent letters.

section.title: 更长话语的基本结构
section.para: 人们通常不会只说一句话。Lojban有多于一句话的说话或写作的明确结构。一个给定的说话事件或写作文本整体被称作一个话语。一个话语中的句子（通常，但不总是bridi）被cmavo ni'o和 i分隔。这些在汉语口语中对应着短暂的停顿（或者什么也不对应），在书面语中对应着象句号、问号和叹号之类的多样的标点。这些分隔符避免了下一句打头的sumti被误认为上一句最后的sumti。
cmavo ni'o分隔（包括不同主题的）段落。在一份长文本或长话语中，文本的话题结构可能由许多 ni'o提示，同时可能用 ni'oni'oni'o指示章， ni'oni'o指示节，单个的 ni'o指示对应于一个汉语段的子话题。
cmavo i分隔句子。他有时与在话语上下文中修饰句子中特定意思（语义）的词构成组合词。（cmavo xu，在 第三章中被讨论，是一个这样的词——它将句子从陈述句转为对真假的提问句（译：即一般疑问句。）当多余一个人在谈论时，一个新的对话者通常将省略 i，即使他/她可能继续相同的话题。
新对话者依然可以在继续前说 i；实际上，最大化的清晰是被鼓励的（因为第二名对话者可能只是在第一名对话者句子后面加词）。好的对 i的翻译为人们非正式谈话时用的 然后： 我做了这个，然后我做了那个，然后……然后……

section.title: 指示词
section.para: 感叹词快览版 情感指示词快览版 指示词快览版 不同文化用各种各样不通常包含在书面语中的腔调和手势表达情绪和态度。部分语言中这些中的一部分被用作感叹词（例如Aha!、Oh no!、Ouch!、Aahh!等），但他们在语言间变化得非常厉害。
Lojban有一组被叫做 感情指示词的特别包含口头陈述中此类评论的cmavo。它们既被写又被说，但不要求特定的腔调或手势。从语法层面来说它们特别简单：bridi开头的一或多个情感词适用于整个bridi；在bridi中任何其他地方的它们适用于最靠近它们的左面的词。例如：

gloss.cmavo: 我高兴因为我正走向漂亮的东西

section.para:
但/和等价 元语言单词快览版 语篇词快览版 不是所有指示词都指示态度。语篇词，与情感指示词有相同语法规则的另一类cmavo，允许关于主话语的某些种类的评论的自由表达。用语篇词允许这些所谓的
元语言特征与接下来的陈述与语法结构之间的清晰分界。通过比较，通过推论的方式指示示例的对比或增加的分量的汉语词汇
但和 也，逻辑上相当于没有话语内容的 然后。通常的汉语使用者没有想过，甚至没意识到， 但基本上意味着 然后的悖论。

证据词快览版 另一组指示词叫做 证据词。证据词展示了说话人与陈述间的关系，特别地，展示了说话者如何得出陈述。这包括
za'a（我直接观察到了关系）、
pe'i（我相信这关系成立）、
ru'a（我假定这关系）和其他的。许多美国印第安语用这种词。

section.para: 时间意义上的时态快览版 tenses快览版 英语中，每个动词第一附着有叫做时态的语法标记：过去时、现在时、将来时。句子

section.title: Lojban语法术语
section.para:
语法术语快览版 这是本章中用的Lojban语法术语的复习，加上一些其他用在本书中的。只包括本身是Lojban词的术语：当然有许多像
中的 指示词的未在此解释的。参见目录以获得关于这些的进一步帮助。

tr.td: bridi定义快览版断言；Lojban表达的基本单位；Lojban句主要种类；某些对象有某关系或某单个对象有某特性的声明。
sumti定义快览版论元；定义在别的某些事物有特定联系的或有某特性的事物的词。参见。
selbri定义快览版逻辑谓语；bridi的中心；明确被sumti指向的对象间关系的词或词组。参见。
cmavo定义快览版Lojban话语的一部分；短小单词；结构词；因为其语法作用而被使用的词。
brivla定义快览版Lojban话语的一部分；内容词；谓语词；能充当selbri；是gismu、lujvo或fu'ivla。参见。
gismu定义快览版根词；一种brivla；有关联rafsi。参见。
lujvo定义快览版复合词；一种brivla；可以也可以不出现在词典中；没有关联rafsi。参见和。
fu'ivla定义快览版借词；一种brivla；可以也可以不出现在词典中；从某非Lojban语言中以调整后的形式借用；通常指文化或自然世界的某些方面；没有关联rafsi。参见。
rafsi定义快览版词的碎片；每个gismu关联一或多个；可以规则集合起来来创造lujvo；独自不是有效单词。参见。
tanru定义快览版两个或多个brivla、可能还有有关的cmavo组成的、来构成selbri的集团，第一个部分修饰第二个部分（基本的）意思。参见。
selma'o定义快览版一组有相同语法功能（若只关心语法，能在句子中相互交换地出现）但意思或其他方面不同的cmavo。参见。
